questions.text: A child presents with recurrent chest infections and abdominal pain. There is a history of 1 blood transfusion in the past. On examination, he had icterus and mild splenomegaly. Electrophoresis shows increased HbA2, HbF, and S spike. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sickle cell disease

 

The given scenario with increased HbA2, HbF, and S spikes on electrophoresis suggests sickle cell disease. It is an autosomal recessive condition.

 

The fundamental molecular lesion: The basic genetic defect in HbS is a single point mutation in one amino acid out of 146 in the hemoglobin molecule—there is a substitution of valine for glutamic acid at the 6-residue position of the beta -globin, producing HbS.  This causes sickle-shaped red blood cells to be produced due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS).

 

Infection, dehydration, and acidosis are all risk factors for sickling.

 

The clinical features of sickle cell disease are due to the tendency of HbS molecules to stack into polymers when deoxygenated. The features are:

 

  • Moderately severe hemolytic anemia with jaundice.
  • Vaso-occlusive phenomenon due to obstruction to capillary blood flow by sickled red cells upon deoxygenation or dehydration:
    • Microinfarcts affecting particularly the abdomen, chest, back and joints and are the cause of recurrent painful crises in SS.
    • Microinfarcts involving most commonly the spleen (splenic sequestration, auto splenectomy), bone marrow (pains), bones (aseptic necrosis, osteomyelitis), lungs.
    • (Pulmonary infections), kidneys (renal cortical necrosis), CNS (stroke), retina (damage) and skin (ulcers), and result in anatomic and functional damage to these organs.
  • Aplastic crisis stems from the infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient cessation of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms like pneumococcal, meningococcal, and Hemophilus influenza septicemia, but can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta thalassemia: Typically presents with severe anemia and requires frequent blood transfusions. Electrophoresis shows increased HbA2 and HbF but does not show a significant S spike.

 

Option B. HbC disease: Characterized by the presence of hemoglobin C, which does not cause the severe symptoms seen in sickle cell disease. Electrophoresis would show HbC rather than HbS.

 

Option D. Acute coronary disease: Not relevant to the presentation described, as it does not explain the recurrent infections, abdominal pain, icterus, and splenomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cell disease is characterized by the presence of HbS, leading to recurrent infections, abdominal pain, hemolytic anemia, and splenomegaly. The diagnosis is confirmed by hemoglobin electrophoresis showing increased HbA2, HbF, and an S spike. The genetic mutation involves the substitution of valine for glutamic acid at the 6th position of the β-globin chain.

questions.text: Acid mucin is stained by _______? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alcian blue

 

MUCIN STAINS:

 

  1. Alcian blue: Stains acid-simple non-sulfated and acid-simple mesenchymal mucins, acid-complex sulfated mucins and acid-complex connective tissue mucins. Does NOT stain neutral mucins
  2. Colloidal iron: Stains acid-simple non-sulfated, acid-simple mesenchymal, acid-complex sulfated mucins. Does NOT stain neutral mucins or acid-complex connective tissue mucins
  3. Mucicarmine: Very specific for epithelial mucins, including adenocarcinomas
  4. PAS (periodic acid-Schiff): Stains glycogen as well as mucins, but tissue can be pre-digested with diastase to remove glycogen. Stains neutral and acid-simple non-sulfated and acid-complex sulfated mucins. Does NOT stain acid-simple mesenchymal mucins and acid-complex connective tissue mucins

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PAS: Stains both glycogen and mucins, but is not as specific as Alcian blue for acid mucins.

 

Option C. Masson trichrome: Primarily used for staining connective tissue (collagen) and is not specific for mucins.

 

Option D. PTAH (Phosphotungstic acid hematoxylin): Typically used for staining muscle striations, fibrin, and glial fibers, not for mucins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcian blue is the preferred stain for identifying acid mucins in tissue samples, distinguishing it from other stains that target different types of mucins or tissue components.

questions.text: A patient presented with a renal stone after a Proteus infection. What is the likely composition of the stone in him? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Magnesium ammonium phosphate

 

Proteus infections are caused by urease-positive organisms that produce urease, an enzyme that breaks down urea into ammonia, leading to alkaline urine. The alkaline environment facilitates the formation of struvite stones, also known as magnesium ammonium phosphate stones or staghorn calculi.

 

These stones are associated with urinary tract infections, especially those caused by urease-positive bacteria like Proteus species.

 

Struvite stones are characterized by their unique "staghorn" appearance, where they form large, branching stones that fill the renal pelvis and calyces. These stones are radiopaque, which means they can be easily detected on a plain X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium phosphate: While calcium phosphate stones can form in alkaline urine, they are not specifically associated with infections by urease-producing bacteria like Proteus. These stones are more commonly linked to other metabolic abnormalities.

 

Option C. Xanthine: Xanthine stones are rare and typically form due to a genetic defect in purine metabolism, unrelated to infections or urinary pH changes. They do not form as a result of Proteus infection.

 

Option D. Cysteine: Cysteine stones are associated with cystinuria, a genetic disorder that leads to excessive cysteine in the urine. These stones typically form in acidic urine and have a distinct hexagonal crystal appearance, unrelated to Proteus infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Magnesium ammonium phosphate (struvite) stones are commonly formed in alkaline urine due to urease-positive bacterial infections, such as those caused by Proteus. They often present as staghorn calculi filling the renal pelvis and calyces.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child presented with fever, fatigue and left ventricular dysfunction. He underwent a cardiac biopsy (image shown). Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lymphocytic myocarditis

 

The clinical presentation of fever, fatigue, and left ventricular dysfunction in a young child, along with the histopathological image from the cardiac biopsy, is suggestive of lymphocytic myocarditis.

 

Lymphocytic Myocarditis:

 

  • Pathology: Characterized by interstitial inflammation with a predominance of lymphocytes. The image provided shows myocardial fibers with an interstitial infiltrate primarily composed of lymphocytes. Associated myocyte necrosis
  • Etiology: Commonly caused by viral infections such as coxsackievirus, adenovirus, and parvovirus B19.
  • Clinical Features: Patients may present with signs and symptoms of heart failure, arrhythmias, and systemic symptoms like fever and fatigue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute rheumatic fever: Typically shows Aschoff bodies with Anitschkow cells on biopsy, which are not present in the provided image.

 

Option C. Chagas disease: Caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, characterized by amastigotes in myocardial cells, often with mixed inflammatory infiltrate, not just lymphocytes.

 

Option D. Pyogenic myocarditis: Characterized by the presence of neutrophils, indicating bacterial infection, which is not seen in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lymphocytic myocarditis is indicated by the presence of lymphocytic infiltration in the myocardium and is commonly associated with viral infections. The clinical presentation includes heart failure symptoms, fever, and fatigue.

 

 

Lymphocytic myocarditis

 

 

Hypersensitivity myocarditis

 

 

Giant cell myocarditis

 

 

Myocarditis of Chagas disease (arrow showing trypanosomes)

questions.text: A patient presented with muscle weakness and wasting, cataracts, and cardiac conduction defects. Genetic testing revealed trinucleotide repeat expansions. Which of the following trinucleotide repeats would be seen in this patient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CTG

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features of muscle weakness, wasting, cataracts, and cardiac conduction defects are hallmark findings of Myotonic Dystrophy. This disorder is caused by an expanded trinucleotide repeat (CTG) in the DMPK gene, leading to the production of abnormal RNA that disrupts normal cellular function, particularly in muscle and cardiac tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GAA: Incorrect. GAA repeat expansion is associated with Friedreich's ataxia, which presents with progressive ataxia, cardiomyopathy, and loss of proprioception.

 

Option C. CAG: Incorrect. CAG repeat expansion is seen in Huntington's disease, characterized by involuntary movements (chorea) and caudate nucleus atrophy.

 

Option D. CGG: Incorrect. CGG repeat expansion is linked to Fragile X syndrome, presenting with intellectual disability, macroorchidism, and facial dysmorphism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myotonic dystrophy is caused by CTG trinucleotide repeat expansions in the DMPK gene, leading to characteristic features including muscle wasting, cataracts, and cardiac conduction defects. Understanding the association between specific trinucleotide repeats and their respective disorders is critical for accurate diagnosis.

questions.text: The fluorescent in situ hybridization cannot be useful for detection of which of the following genetic defects?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Point mutation

 

Point mutation: Point mutations involve a change in a single nucleotide base pair, which FISH cannot detect because it is designed to detect larger structural changes. For detecting point mutations, more sensitive techniques like polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and specific variants such as single base primer extension assays are used.

 

Other Options:

 

Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) is a molecular cytogenetic technique that uses fluorescent probes binding parts of the chromosome to detect and localize the presence or absence of specific DNA sequences. It is particularly useful for identifying genetic abnormalities such as deletions, amplifications, and translocations by visualizing the chromosomal location of the gene of interest.

 

Option A. Deletion: FISH can detect deletions by showing the absence of a fluorescent signal where the probe should bind.

 

Option C. Amplification: FISH can detect gene amplifications by showing multiple fluorescent signals in the region of interest.

 

Option D: Translocation: FISH can detect translocations by showing split signals in different parts of the chromosome or in different chromosomes, indicating that parts of the chromosome have been rearranged.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FISH is not suitable for detecting point mutations but is effective for identifying larger genetic abnormalities such as deletions, amplifications, and translocations.

questions.text: Match the following cells with their locations: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-b, 2-a, 3-c, 4-d  

 

The correct matches for the cells and their respective locations are as follows:

 

  1. Kupffer cells (b) Liver: Kupffer cells are specialized macrophages located in the liver, involved in the breakdown of red blood cells and the immune response within the liver.
  2. Parietal cells (a) Stomach: Parietal cells are found in the lining of the stomach and are responsible for secreting hydrochloric acid (HCl), which aids in digestion.
  3. Dust cells (c) Alveoli: Dust cells, also known as alveolar macrophages, are found in the alveoli of the lungs. They play a crucial role in removing inhaled particles and pathogens from the alveolar spaces.
  4. Clara cells (d) Bronchioles: Clara cells, now more commonly referred to as club cells, are found in the bronchioles of the lungs. They secrete surfactant proteins and detoxify harmful substances inhaled into the lungs.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter
Defective peristalsis
Decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus
Decreased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the pathology of achalasia cardia? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus 

 

Achalasia cardia is characterized by decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus.

 

The LES relaxes during swallowing due to the release of nitric oxide and vasoactive intestinal polypeptide from inhibitory neurons, as well as the interruption of normal cholinergic signaling. These inhibitory neurons degenerate in achalasia cardia, resulting in decreased NO and VIP release. This results in increased LES tone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter: This is incorrect. In achalasia cardia, there is incomplete relaxation of the LES, not relaxation.

 

Option B. Defective peristalsis: While this statement is related to achalasia cardia, it is not the most accurate or complete description of the pathology. The correct answer focuses specifically on the decreased release of NO and VIP, which directly explains the increased LES tone and subsequent symptoms.

 

Option D. Decreased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter: This is incorrect. In achalasia cardia, the tone of the LES is increased, not decreased.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triad of achalasia cardia is as follows:

 

  1. Incomplete relaxation of LES
  2. Increased tone of LES
  3. Absent peristalsis (aperistalsis)

questions.text: By which cell of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma arises? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Naive B cells

 

The cell of origin of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)/ Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (SLL) is either naïve B cells or post-germinal centre memory B cell.

 

 

 

FCL = Follicular Cell Lymphoma; MALT = Marginal Zone Lymphoma of Mucosa-Associated Lymphoid Tissue; MCL = Mantle Cell Lymphoma; SLL/CLL = Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma/Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mature B cells: While mature B cells can give rise to certain types of lymphomas, CLL/SLL specifically arises from naive B cells or post-germinal center memory B cells.

 

Option B. Mature T cells: Mature T cells are associated with different types of lymphomas, such as T-cell lymphomas, not CLL/SLL.

 

Option C. Progenitor T cells: Progenitor T cells are involved in the development of T-cell leukemias and lymphomas, such as T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia, not CLL/SLL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma arises from naive B cells or post-germinal center memory B cells, distinguishing it from other B-cell and T-cell malignancies.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used to store blood for up to 42 days? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Citrate Phosphate Dextrose Adenine – 2

 

Explanation:

 

Citrate-phosphate-dextrose adenine – 2 (CPDA-2) is an advanced anticoagulant and preservative solution that can extend blood storage life up to 42 days. This solution improves red blood cell metabolism and ATP levels, ensuring better viability of stored blood. CPDA-2 is particularly useful in modern blood banking for maximizing storage durations while maintaining transfusion efficacy.

 

Other Options:

 

Acid Citrate Dextrose (ACD): 21 days. It is one of the earliest anticoagulant solutions but has a shorter shelf life compared to CPDA.

 

Citrate Phosphate Dextrose (CPD): 21 days. Although CPD is an improvement over ACD, it cannot store blood as long as CPDA solutions.

 

Citrate Phosphate 2 Dextrose (CP2D): 21 days. This modification of CPD does not extend the storage life significantly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Citrate Phosphate Dextrose Adenine (CPDA-2) allows blood storage for up to 42 days, offering the longest preservation capability compared to earlier anticoagulant solutions. This highlights advancements in blood preservation methods and their clinical importance.

 

Note: CPDA-1 (35 days)

choices.text: Naive B cells in Interfollicular zones

questions.text: Origin of B cell in CLL/SLL is: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Naive B cells in Interfollicular zones

 

In CLL/SLL, B cells originate from naive B cell or Pre/Post Germinal Centre memory B cell. CLL arises in the lymph node.

 

DNA sequencing has revealed that the Ig genes of some CLL/SLL are somatically hypermutated, whereas others are not, suggesting that the cell of origin may be either a post germinal center memory B cell or a naïve B cell. For unclear reasons, tumors with unmutated Ig segments (those putatively of naive B-cell origin) pursue a more aggressive course

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Centrocytes: Centrocytes are B cells located in the germinal center of lymphoid follicles, where they undergo selection during the immune response. However, they are not the origin of CLL/SLL, as CLL/SLL originates from naive B cells or memory B cells, not centrocytes.

 

Option B. Extranodal mature Peripheral B cells: While peripheral B cells are involved in immune responses, the origin of CLL/SLL is not from these mature peripheral B cells but rather from naive B cells within interfollicular zones.

 

Option D. Bone Marrow Progenitors: Bone marrow progenitors are the precursors of various blood cells, including B cells, but they are not the immediate origin of the B cells involved in CLL/SLL. CLL/SLL originates from more differentiated B cells, specifically naive B cells in interfollicular zones or memory B cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The origin of B cells in CLL/SLL is primarily from naive B cells in interfollicular zones or post-germinal center memory B cells. Tumors originating from naive B cells, as indicated by unmutated Ig segments, tend to pursue a more aggressive course.

questions.text: Perl’s stain is used to demonstrate which of the following in tissues? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Hemosiderin

 

Explanation: 

 

Perl's stain (also known as Prussian blue stain) is specifically used to demonstrate hemosiderin in tissues. Hemosiderin is an iron-storage complex that appears as blue granules when stained with Perl's stain. This staining technique is particularly useful in detecting iron deposits in tissues, which occurs in conditions like hemosiderosis or hemochromatosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fat - Fat in tissues is typically demonstrated using special fat stains such as Oil Red O or Sudan stains, not Perl's stain. These fat stains work on frozen sections as lipids are dissolved by the solvents used in routine tissue processing.

 

Option C. Reticulin - Reticulin fibers are demonstrated using silver stains like Gordon and Sweet's silver stain, which highlights the thin reticular fibers in black or dark brown. Perl's stain does not demonstrate reticulin.

 

Option D. Fibrin - Fibrin is typically demonstrated using special stains like Phosphotungstic Acid-Hematoxylin (PTAH) or Martius Scarlet Blue (MSB) stain, which color fibrin red or blue depending on the stain used. Perl's stain does not demonstrate fibrin.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Perl's stain (Prussian blue) is specifically used to detect iron deposits like hemosiderin in tissues, appearing as blue granules, and is valuable in diagnosing iron overload disorders and conditions with abnormal iron metabolism.

questions.text: Which of the following is the major source of plasma von-Willebrand factor? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endothelial cells

 

vWF is made in endothelial cells and megakaryocytes. vWF is also present in the subendothelial matrix of normal blood vessels and the α-granules of platelets. Following endothelial injury, exposure of subendothelial vWF causes adhesion of platelets, primarily via the glycoprotein lb (GpIB) platelet receptor.

 

  • Endothelial cells are responsible for producing and secreting the majority of plasma vWF. They synthesize vWF and store it in Weibel-Palade bodies, specialized storage granules in the endothelial cells. Upon vascular injury, vWF is released into the bloodstream, where it binds to platelets and subendothelial structures, facilitating the formation of a platelet plug.
  • Additionally, megakaryocytes synthesize vWF, which is stored in the alpha granules of platelets and released during platelet activation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Platelets: While platelets contain vWF in their alpha granules and release it upon activation, they are not the major source of plasma vWF. Instead, their vWF contributes to local hemostasis at the site of injury.

 

Option B. Lymphocytes: Lymphocytes are a type of white blood cell involved in the immune response and do not produce or release vWF.

 

Option C. Macrophages: Macrophages are involved in phagocytosis and the immune response, but they do not produce vWF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The major source of plasma von Willebrand factor (vWF) is endothelial cells, which release vWF into the bloodstream upon vascular injury to facilitate platelet adhesion.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1253

questions.text: Classical Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells expressing CD15 and CD30 are seen in: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mixed cellularity Hodgkin lymphoma

 

Explanation:

 

Classical Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells are a hallmark of classical Hodgkin lymphoma (CHL), including subtypes like mixed cellularity and nodular sclerosis. These RS cells have large, multinucleated nuclei with prominent nucleoli ("owl-eye" appearance) and express CD15 and CD30. Among the subtypes of CHL, mixed cellularity Hodgkin lymphoma is associated with abundant classical RS cells within a mixed inflammatory background.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nodular lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin lymphoma: Incorrect. This subtype is characterized by L&H (popcorn) variant RS cells, which do not express CD15 or CD30 but are positive for B-cell markers like CD20.

 

Option C. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma: Incorrect. RS cells are not a feature of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. This group includes many diverse lymphoid neoplasms, each with distinct cytological and immunophenotypic features.

 

Option D. Burkitt lymphoma: Incorrect. Burkitt lymphoma is a high-grade B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterized by a "starry-sky" appearance due to interspersed macrophages, not by RS cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classical Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells, which express CD15 and CD30, are a defining feature of classical Hodgkin lymphoma, particularly in subtypes like mixed cellularity and nodular sclerosis. Recognizing the immunophenotypic markers of RS cells is critical for distinguishing Hodgkin lymphoma subtypes from other lymphoid malignancies.

questions.text: What is the most common site for an extragonadal germ cell tumor? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mediastinum

 

Extragonadal germ cell tumor is most commonly seen in mediastinum.

 

Extragonadal germinal cell tumors (EGGCTs) are rare tumors that predominantly affect young males.

 

These tumors are particularly significant because they mimic the normal germ cell tumors but appear in unusual locations, making them a critical diagnostic challenge. The prevalence of EGGCTs in the mediastinum indicates the importance of considering this location when evaluating patients with symptoms suggestive of germ cell tumors but without testicular or ovarian masses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pineal gland: While EGGCTs can occur here, they represent only about 5% of cases.

 

Option B. Retroperitoneum: This site accounts for 30-40% of EGGCT cases, making it the second most common site.

 

Option C. Sacrococcygeal region: This is the least common site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common sites of extragonadal germ cell tumor –

 

  • Mediastinum (50-70%)
  • Retroperitoneum (30-40%)
  • Pineal gland (5%)
  • Sacrococcygeal area (less than 5%)

questions.text: A 6-foot 5-inch man undergoing a routine physical examination was found to have an early diastolic murmur. His family pedigree chart is given below. Identify the mode of inheritance of this condition: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autosomal dominant

 

Notice that the disease is present in all 3 generations. It is being transmitted with equal frequency from affected father to his daughters and son. So, it is autosomal dominant mode of inheritance.  The patient's height and the presence of early diastolic murmur in the given clinical scenario are suggestive of Marfan syndrome

 

Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects connective tissue, including the skeleton, cardiovascular system, and eyes.

 

Important features of Marfan syndrome:

 

  • Tall stature with disproportionately long limbs and fingers (arachnodactyly)
  • Aortic root dilation, which can lead to aortic aneurysm and dissection
  • Mitral valve prolapses
  • Lens dislocation, which can cause visual impairment or blindness
  • Skeletal abnormalities, such as scoliosis and chest deformities
  • Stretch marks (striae) on the skin that are not related to weight gain or loss
  • Joint hypermobility
  • Autosomal dominant inheritance

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Marfan syndrome is made based on clinical features and genetic testing. Treatment typically involves management of cardiovascular complications, such as regular monitoring of the aorta and prophylactic aortic surgery, if necessary, as well as management of other symptoms such as lens dislocation and skeletal abnormalities.

choices.text: Herpes virus
Verruca vulgaris
Molluscum contagiosum

questions.text: A 36-year-old male with skin-colored umbilicated papules. Microscopy is as shown below. The most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Molluscum contagiosum

 

The given picture shows intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (staining purple-pink) within the keratinocytes.

 

Molluscum contagiosum is a common self-limiting contagious lesion caused by a poxvirus which is a DNA virus. It is more common in children and young adults. Infection is acquired by direct contact. Clinically, the lesions are often multiple, discrete, waxy, papules, about 5 mm in diameter and are seen more frequently on the face and trunk

 

Tzanck smear shows intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson-Patterson bodies), the largest known inclusion bodies (30-35 m).

 

 

Individual lesions are firm, pruritic, pink to skin-colored umbilicated papules (shown below). A curd-like material can be expressed from the central umbilication

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes virus: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections typically present with grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, which then progress to pustules, ulcers, and crusts. The histology usually shows multinucleated giant cells with intranuclear inclusions on a Tzanck smear, not the intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies seen in this case.

 

Option B. Verruca vulgaris: Also known as common warts, verruca vulgaris is caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV). These lesions are typically hyperkeratotic, exophytic papules with a rough surface. Histologically, they show papillomatosis, hyperkeratosis, and koilocytosis (vacuolated cells with a halo around the nucleus). These features are distinct from the molluscum bodies seen in Molluscum contagiosum.

 

Option D. Lichen planus: Lichen planus is an inflammatory condition that presents with pruritic, polygonal, flat-topped, violaceous papules, often with Wickham striae (fine white lines) on the surface. Histologically, it shows a band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermoepidermal junction, hypergranulosis, and saw-toothing of the rete ridges. These findings are not consistent with the histological image provided, which shows molluscum bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Molluscum contagiosum is characterized by the presence of intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson-Patterson bodies) within keratinocytes, and it presents clinically as skin-colored, umbilicated papules.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 1940

questions.text: All of the following parameters are true for anemia of chronic disease except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decrease in serum ferritin

 

Anemia of chronic disease (ACD), also known as anemia of inflammation, is a common type of anemia that occurs in the context of chronic infections (like TB, chronic osteomyelitis), autoimmune diseases (RA,IBD), cancer, and other chronic conditions. It is characterized by several key features related to iron metabolism and the body's response to inflammation.

 

This statement is incorrect. Serum ferritin is an acute-phase reactant, meaning its levels increase in response to inflammation. Therefore, in ACD, serum ferritin levels are typically increased or normal, not decreased. Ferritin acts as a marker of iron stores, and in ACD, iron stores are usually normal or increased, but the iron is not readily available for use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in serum hepcidin: Hepcidin is a peptide hormone produced by the liver that regulates iron homeostasis. In ACD, hepcidin levels are increased due to inflammation. Hepcidin inhibits iron absorption from the gut and the release of iron from macrophages, leading to reduced availability of iron for erythropoiesis.

 

Option C. Associated with conditions like TB: ACD is often associated with chronic infections and inflammatory diseases. The chronic inflammation leads to the production of cytokines like IL-6, which increase hepcidin production and subsequently cause the anemia.

 

Option D. Normal iron stores: Iron stores in ACD are usually normal or increased. The issue in ACD is not the lack of iron but rather the body's inability to utilize the iron effectively due to the inflammatory response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serum ferritin levels increase in anemia of chronic disease.

 

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1234

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is primarily mediated by immune complexes? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

 

Explanation:

 

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is primarily an immune complex-mediated autoimmune disease. It is characterized by the formation of autoantibodies, especially antinuclear antibodies (ANA), which bind to nuclear antigens released from apoptotic cells. These antigen-antibody complexes deposit in tissues, triggering complement activation and inflammation, which cause tissue damage. The kidneys (lupus nephritis), skin, joints, and blood vessels are commonly affected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sarcoidosis: Incorrect. Sarcoidosis is a T-cell-mediated disease involving granuloma formation, predominantly driven by CD4+ T-helper cells. It is not mediated by immune complexes.

 

Option C. Myasthenia gravis: Incorrect. Myasthenia gravis is an antibody-mediated autoimmune disease targeting acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction. It does not involve immune complexes.

 

Option D. Asthma: Incorrect. Asthma is a chronic inflammatory airway disease primarily mediated by IgE, mast cells, and eosinophils. While immune complexes are not the primary drivers, T-cells do contribute to the inflammation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SLE is a prototype immune complex-mediated autoimmune disease. Recognizing the role of immune complexes in its pathogenesis helps distinguish it from other autoimmune conditions that may be T-cell- or antibody-mediated. Understanding these mechanisms is crucial for targeted therapeutic approaches.

questions.text: A patient undergoing long-term hemodialysis for chronic renal failure presents with symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome. Which of the following is the chemical nature of the amyloid responsible for this condition? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) β2-Microglobulin (Aβ2M)

 

Explanation:

 

Hemodialysis-associated amyloidosis (HAA) is a condition that arises in patients undergoing long-term hemodialysis, often for chronic renal failure. The amyloid deposits in this condition are composed of β2-Microglobulin (Aβ2M). Normally filtered by the kidneys, β2-microglobulin accumulates in patients with renal failure, especially during prolonged dialysis, as dialysis membranes are often inefficient at removing this protein. The deposition of Aβ2M amyloid fibrils is particularly associated with osteoarticular structures, leading to symptoms like carpal tunnel syndrome and joint pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transthyretin (TTR): Incorrect. Transthyretin amyloidosis (ATTR) is seen in systemic senile amyloidosis and familial amyloid polyneuropathies, with cardiac or nerve involvement.

 

Option B. Serum Amyloid A (SAA): Incorrect. SAA amyloidosis is secondary to chronic inflammation, such as tuberculosis or rheumatoid arthritis, and is associated with AA amyloid.

 

Option C. Light Chains (AL): Incorrect. Light chain amyloidosis (AL) is typically seen in plasma cell dyscrasias, such as multiple myeloma, where amyloid is derived from monoclonal immunoglobulin light chains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with long-term hemodialysis can develop β2-Microglobulin (Aβ2M) amyloidosis, primarily affecting osteoarticular structures. Recognizing this condition is essential for diagnosing and managing complications associated with prolonged renal replacement therapy.

 

Additional Information

 

A. Generalized/Systemic Amyloidosis

 

 

B. Localised Amyloidosis

 

 

C. Hereditary Amyloidosis

choices.text: Suprabasal acantholytic blister is a characteristic feature

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with painful blisters on the skin and oral mucosa. Direct immunofluorescence is given below. Which of the following is false regarding the same? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antibiotics against hemidesmosomes

 

The given image shows a characteristic fish-net appearance on direct immunofluorescence, which is diagnostic of pemphigus vulgaris.

 

The question talking about the false statement.

 

In direct immunofluorescence testing for pemphigus vulgaris, the immunoglobulin deposition is observed along the plasma membranes of epidermal keratinocytes in a reticular or fishnet-like pattern, indicating an autoantibody attack against desmosomal adhesion proteins. This results in early suprabasal separation and loss of cell-to-cell adhesion (acantholysis). The severity and position of the blisters are related to the distribution of desmoglein 1 and 3 in the epidermis and the presence of autoantibodies to one or both proteins. The antibodies primarily disrupt the intercellular adhesive function of the desmosomes and may activate intercellular proteases. The observed pattern is due to the interepidermal intercellular deposition of IgG and C3. The Tzanck smear is the preferred initial test, which involves collecting material from the floor of a fresh blister for microscopic examination, using Giemsa or Romanowsky stain. The presence of Tzank cells confirms the diagnosis.

 

This is incorrect and hence the false statement. Hemidesmosomes are associated with a different condition called bullous pemphigoid, where autoantibodies target components of the basement membrane, not the desmosomes as in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibodies against desmoglein 3: This statement is true, as pemphigus vulgaris involves antibodies against desmoglein 3, particularly in mucosal lesions.

 

Option B. Antibodies against desmoglein 1: This statement is also true. Pemphigus vulgaris can involve antibodies against desmoglein 1, which is primarily found in the superficial layers of the skin.

 

Option C. Suprabasal acantholytic blister is a characteristic feature: This is correct, as pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by suprabasal blisters formed due to acantholysis, resulting from the disruption of desmosomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by autoantibodies against desmosomal proteins (desmoglein 1 and 3), leading to a suprabasal acantholytic blister and a diagnostic fish-net appearance on direct immunofluorescence.

questions.text: A biopsy was taken from the lymph node. What is name of the cell found in the lymph node? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RS cell

 

In the given image Reed-Sternberg cells are seen, which is seen in Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Reed-Sternberg cells marker -

  • CDI5
  • CD30 (most sensitive)
  • PAX-5 (most SPECIFIC)

 

RS cells are large and either multi-nucleated or have a bilobed nucleus which resemble as "owl's eye"

 

Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells are large, abnormal lymphocytes that are characteristic of Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL). There are four main types of HL, each with a different pattern of RS cell morphology.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mott cell: These are plasma cells containing multiple globules of immunoglobulin and are not associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Option C. Popcorn cell: This is a variant of RS cells seen in NLPHL, not the classic type shown in the image.

 

Option D. Plasma cell: These are antibody-producing cells derived from B-lymphocytes, not the characteristic cells in Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells, identifiable by their "owl's eye" appearance, are characteristic of Hodgkin's lymphoma and can be identified using markers like CD15, CD30, and PAX-5.

choices.text: Infectious Mononucleosis
CMV infection

questions.text: The following cells seen in the lymph node are indicative of: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Measles

 

The pathognomonic slide for measles is presented. A Warthin-Finkeldey giant cell with sizable clusters of inclusion bodies that resemble grapes may be seen on this image of a lymph node biopsy.

 

The Warthin-Finkeldey cells, which are randomly distributed multinucleate giant cells with eosinophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies, massive germinal centres, and noticeable follicular hyperplasia are typical features of lymphoid organs.

 

These are pathognomonic of measles and are also found in the lung and sputum. Kimura illness, measles, lymph nodes in HIV+ people, and other disorders are frequently associated with Warthin-Finkeldey type polykaryocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infectious Mononucleosis: This condition typically shows atypical lymphocytes, not multinucleate giant cells with inclusion bodies.

 

Option C. CMV infection: CMV infections lead to the formation of "owl's eye" inclusion bodies predominantly in cells, different from the grape-like clusters seen in measles.

 

Option D. Influenza: Influenza primarily affects the respiratory epithelium and does not lead to the formation of multinucleate giant cells in lymph nodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells with eosinophilic inclusion bodies resembling grape clusters in a lymph node biopsy is pathognomonic of measles.

choices.text: Causes metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop
Prevents the cells from sticking to the slide surface

questions.text: What is the function of Acetone Free Methanol in Leishman stain? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Causes metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop

Acetone-free methanol serves as a fixing agent in the Leishman stain process. Its primary function is to cause metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop, which preserves cellular architecture. This fixation occurs through protein denaturation and halts all biological processes, maintaining the cellular structure for microscopic examination. Therefore, the correct choice would be: "Causes metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop."

 

The procedure of Leishman stain:

  • Freshly prepare and rapidly air-dry blood film.
  • Cover the film with Leishman's Stain (S018S) and allow it to act for 1 minute. Methanol in the stain fixes the preparation.
  • Add double the volume of distilled water to the slide and mix.
  • Allow the diluted stain to act for 10-12 minutes.
  • Wash the film with distilled water or phosphate buffer of pH 7.0, drain and dry in air and examine

 

Other Options:

Option B. Prevents the cells from sticking to the slide surface: This is incorrect because methanol doesn't prevent adhesion; rather, it preserves cellular structure through protein denaturation.

 

Option C. Colors the red cells: This is not the role of acetone-free methanol. The actual coloring of the cells is performed by the dye components in the Leishman stain (methylene blue and eosin).

 

Option D. Fixes cells to slide: While methanol is a fixative, its primary mechanism is stopping metabolic activity, not adhering cells to the slide. As previously noted, adhesion to the slide surface is the function of substances like albumin.
 

Educational Objective:


Acetone-free methanol in the Leishman stain primarily functions by causing metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop through protein denaturation, which preserves cellular architecture and enables proper staining and microscopic examination.

questions.text:
Organize the given steps of Karyotyping into the accurate sequence. (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Collect cells by peripheral vein using a heparin syringe
  2. Culture in phytohaemoagglutinin
  3. Incubation at 37°C for 3 days
  4. Harvest with colchicine
  5. Routine staining with Giemsa
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4, 5

 

Karyotyping is a process that allows for the visualization of chromosomes in a cell, usually to diagnose genetic diseases, identify chromosomal abnormalities, or analyze chromosomal structures. The accurate sequence for conducting karyotyping involves several key steps, each critical to ensuring accurate results.

 

  1. Collect cells by peripheral vein using a heparin syringe: Blood is typically drawn from a peripheral vein using a syringe containing heparin, an anticoagulant that prevents blood from clotting, thereby preserving the cells for further processing.
  2. Culture in phytohaemoagglutinin: The collected cells, which contain lymphocytes, are then cultured in a medium containing phytohaemoagglutinin (PHA), a mitogen that stimulates lymphocytes to enter mitosis. This step is crucial because chromosomes are most easily visualized and analyzed during mitosis.
  3. Incubation at 37°C for 3 days: The cell culture is incubated at 37 degrees Celsius for approximately 3 days to allow the cells to grow and divide, ensuring a sufficient number of cells reach the metaphase stage of mitosis.
  4. Harvest with colchicine: Colchicine is added to the culture to arrest cells in metaphase by disrupting the mitotic spindle formation. This ensures that a large number of cells are caught in metaphase, where chromosomes are most condensed and visible for karyotyping.
  5. Routine staining with Giemsa: After harvesting, the cells are fixed, dropped onto a slide, and stained with Giemsa stain. This stain provides a distinct banding pattern on the chromosomes, which helps in identifying and analyzing the structure and number of chromosomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The accurate sequence for conducting Karyotyping is outlined below:

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with lower back pain and fever. She has elevated amylase levels and has experienced similar episodes in the past as well. Which type of necrosis is likely to be present? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fat necrosis

 

The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of pancreatitis, including lower back pain, fever, elevated amylase levels, and a history of chronic alcohol use. Pancreatitis is a condition where inflammation of the pancreas occurs, often due to long-term alcohol consumption.

 

In pancreatitis, the digestive enzymes, particularly lipases, are released into the pancreas and surrounding tissues, leading to the breakdown of fat cells. This enzymatic activity causes fat necrosis, a process where fatty acids combine with calcium to form chalky white areas known as saponification. This type of necrosis is characteristic of chronic pancreatitis.

 

The most common precipitating factor for an acute pancreatitis attack is cholelithiasis (gallstones). Chronic pancreatitis, on the other hand, is typically associated with a long-standing history of alcohol intake.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coagulative necrosis: Typically occurs in ischemic conditions (except in the brain) and is not associated with the enzymatic activity seen in pancreatitis.

 

Option B. Caseous necrosis: Commonly associated with tuberculosis, it has a cheese-like appearance and is not related to pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Fibrinoid necrosis: Involves immune complex deposition in blood vessels and is seen in conditions like vasculitis and certain autoimmune diseases, not in pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fat necrosis is a hallmark of pancreatitis, particularly in the context of chronic alcohol use. It is caused by the action of pancreatic enzymes on surrounding fat tissue, leading to saponification and calcium deposition.

choices.text: Telomere stability is associated with aging
Abnormal telomerase activation is associated with aging
Decreased telomere length is associated with aging
Increased telomere length is associated with aging

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding the telomerase theory of aging? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreased telomere length is associated with aging.

 

  • Telomeres are short, TG-rich repeated DNA sequences found at the ends of linear eukaryotic chromosomes. Telomeres do not contain any protein coding sequences. They are necessary for the complete replication of chromosome ends as well as the protection of the ends from fusion and degradation.
  • Telomeres at the ends of chromosomes are normally shortened with each cell division. Cell-cycle arrest or apoptosis may result if telomeres are shortened beyond a certain point. This is referred to as replicative senescence.
  • Telomerase is an enzyme that prevents telomeres from shortening. It is a specialized RNA-protein complex that adds nucleotides to the ends of chromosomes by using its own RNA as a template.
  • This enzyme is found in germ cells but not in most somatic cells. As a result, the majority of somatic cells age, their telomeres shorten, and they exit the cell cycle, rendering them unable to generate new cells to replace damaged cells.
  • In somatic cells, abnormal telomerase reactivation causes senescence and apoptosis. It allows the cells to divide more than usual.
  • Telomerase is usually reactivated in stem cells and cancer cells, and telomere length is stabilized, allowing the cells to proliferate indefinitely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased telomere length is associated with aging. Telomeres shorten with each cell division, leading to cell-cycle arrest or apoptosis when they become critically short, contributing to the aging process. Telomerase helps prevent this shortening but is typically inactive in most somatic cells, leading to aging and limited cell division capability.

questions.text: Which of the following is the mode of inheritance shown by the pedigree analysis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) AR

 

The fact that there is an affected patient with no disease manifesting in the parents is suggestive of the fact that the parents are heterozygous for the particular gene and the child manifests the disease due to being homozygous for the particular genes. So, we are dealing with an autosomal recessive disease.   

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. AD (Autosomal Dominant): In an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, affected individuals have at least one affected parent, and the disease appears in every generation.

 

Option C. XLR (X-linked Recessive): This pattern typically affects males more frequently and is passed through carrier females. The affected males do not pass the gene to their sons but can pass it to their daughters, who become carriers.

 

Option D. XLD (X-linked Dominant): Both males and females can be affected, and the disease does not skip generations. Affected males pass the gene to all daughters but none of their sons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An autosomal recessive inheritance pattern is characterized by the presence of affected individuals with unaffected parents, indicating that the parents are carriers and the disease manifests when two recessive alleles are inherited.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest marker for myocardial infarction? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ischemia modified albumin

 

Ischemia-modified albumin (IMA) is considered one of the earliest markers for myocardial infarction (MI). It can be detected in the blood within minutes of ischemia and before any significant myocardial necrosis occurs.

 

The novelty of IMA lies in its ability to indicate ischemia even before traditional markers like CK-MB or Troponin I rise, making it particularly useful in the early diagnosis of MI. Its primary utility, however, is in its negative predictive value—if IMA levels are normal, it's more likely that the patient is not experiencing an MI.

 

Additionally,

 

Heart Fatty Acid Binding Protein (H-FABP), one more novel early marker is noted for its rapid response following myocardial injury. It can be detected early in the blood after the onset of a heart attack, making it a valuable tool for early diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CK-MB: CK-MB is a marker of myocardial injury that typically rises within 3-4 hours after the onset of infarction.

 

Option B. Lactate dehydrogenase 1 (LDH 1): LDH 1 is a late marker of myocardial infarction, typically rising 24-48 hours after the onset.

 

Note - LDH reacts with Triphenyl Tetrazole Chloride dye, which is used to visually differentiate between normal and infarcted cardiac tissue during diagnostic procedures. In the presence of this dye, normal cardiac tissue produces a big red color, while infarcted areas show a yellowish appearance. This color differentiation helps in identifying and assessing the extent of myocardial damage.

 

Option C. Cardiac Troponin I: Cardiac Troponins, especially Troponin I, are highly specific for myocardial injury and are the gold standard for diagnosing MI. However, they typically rise within 4-6 hours after the onset, making them less useful as the earliest marker compared to IMA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ischemia modified albumin (IMA) is an early biomarker for myocardial infarction, detectable shortly after ischemia begins, and is particularly valuable for its ability to rule out MI when levels are normal.

choices.text: Anthracotic pigment

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with cough, fatigability, and weight loss. He was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) on bronchoscopy. The resected specimen had a hilar lymph node that was 1cm in size and showed a black pigment. What is the black pigment likely to be? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anthracotic pigment

 

The black pigment in the resected bronchoscopic specimen's hilar lymph node is most likely an anthracotic pigment.

 

The black colour is caused by carbon particle deposition. Carbon particles inhaled are engulfed by lung macrophages and transported to the hilar lymph nodes. This builds up and causes anthracosis, or blackening of the lung tissues.

 

 

It is commonly seen in people who work in environments with high levels of carbon particle pollution, such as coal mines. It is also the most common exogenous pigment found in humans as a result of urban air pollution. The aggregates of the carbon dust may induce fibroblastic reaction or emphysema that may lead to a condition called coal worker's pneumoconiosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanin: Melanin is a natural pigment found in the skin, hair, and eyes. It is not typically found in the lungs or lymph nodes.

 

Option C. Lipochrome: Lipochrome (also known as lipofuscin) is a yellow-brown pigment that accumulates with age in various tissues, but it does not present as black and is not typically found in the lungs or lymph nodes.

 

Option D. Hemosiderin: Hemosiderin is an iron-storage complex and presents as a golden-brown pigment. It is associated with hemorrhage and iron metabolism but does not appear as black.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anthracotic pigment, resulting from the deposition of carbon particles, is the most likely cause of the black pigment observed in the hilar lymph node of a patient with squamous cell carcinoma. This is common in individuals exposed to high levels of environmental pollution or occupational hazards involving carbon particles.

choices.text: Aschoff's bodies
Epithelioid granuloma
Granulomatous vasculitis

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient presented to the outpatient department with migratory arthritis and examination revealed a pan-systolic murmur. An echocardiography was performed which was suggestive of mitral regurgitation. A biopsy specimen was obtained and the image is provided below. What is the most likely lesion shown in the histopathology slide? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aschoff’s bodies

 

Acute rheumatic fever is suggested by the clinical findings of migratory arthritis, pan-systolic murmur, and mitral regurgitation. Aschoff's bodies are the most likely lesion in the histopathological slide.

 

Acute RF causes focal inflammatory lesions in a variety of tissues. Aschoff bodies are distinct lesions in the heart that consist of foci of lymphocytes (primarily T cells), occasional plasma cells, and plump activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells (pathognomonic for RF). These macrophages have a lot of cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin in a central, slender, wavy ribbon (hence the name "caterpillar cells"), and they can get multinucleated.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epithelioid granuloma: Epithelioid granulomas are associated with chronic inflammatory conditions such as tuberculosis or sarcoidosis. They do not have the characteristic Anitschkow cells seen in Aschoff bodies.

 

Option  C. Granulomatous vasculitis: Granulomatous vasculitis is characterized by granulomas in the walls of blood vessels, which is seen in conditions like granulomatosis with polyangiitis. It does not match the histological description of Aschoff bodies.

 

Option D. Granuloma inguinale: Granuloma inguinale, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, presents with genital ulcers and Donovan bodies on histology, which is unrelated to the cardiac findings described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aschoff bodies, which consist of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and characteristic Anitschkow cells, are the hallmark histological feature of acute rheumatic fever, a condition that can lead to significant cardiac involvement, including mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: Clathrin mediated ingestion in cells are for: (NEET 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endocytosis

 

Explanation:

 

Clathrin-mediated endocytosis is a fundamental cellular process where cells internalize various molecules and particles from their surroundings using clathrin-coated vesicles. This type of endocytosis is crucial for the uptake of nutrients, receptors, and other molecules. Clathrin, a protein, plays a key role by forming a coated pit that facilitates the invagination of the cell membrane and the formation of a vesicle that engulfs the extracellular material.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pinocytosis: Though a form of endocytosis involving the ingestion of liquid, it does not specifically require clathrin. It generally involves smaller vesicles and can occur through clathrin-dependent and clathrin-independent pathways.

 

Option B. Phagocytosis: Involves the ingestion of large particles and is generally not mediated by clathrin. It is typically performed by specialized cells such as macrophages and neutrophils.

 

Option D. Exocytosis: This process involves the expulsion of materials from the cell, not ingestion, and thus does not involve clathrin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clathrin-mediated endocytosis is essential for the internalization of various biomolecules and particles through specific, receptor-mediated processes, distinguishing it from other types of cellular ingestion such as pinocytosis and phagocytosis.

questions.text:
Which of the statements below accurately pertain to amyloidosis? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. It is an extracellular protein.
  2. It is called amyloid because of starch like deposition.
  3. Beta-pleated sheets are seen on X-ray crystallography
  4. AL is a secondary type of amyloidosis.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3  

 

Amyloidosis is a group of diseases characterized by the deposition of abnormal, misfolded proteins in tissues. These proteins form beta-pleated sheets, which can be detected using X-ray crystallography.

 

1. Extracellular protein: Amyloid is an extracellular deposit of abnormal proteins that form non-branching fibrils. These fibrils are composed primarily of misfolded protein subunits that aggregate into an insoluble form.

 

2. Amyloid and starch like deposition: The term "amyloid" is derived from the word "amylum," meaning starch. The term was historically used because amyloid deposits initially stained with iodine, similar to starch. However, amyloid is NOT starch but has similar staining characteristics. (starch-like)

 

3. Beta-pleated sheets: A defining feature of amyloid is the presence of beta-pleated sheet structures in the fibrils. This secondary structure can be identified through techniques such as X-ray crystallography and is crucial for the amyloid's characteristic properties.

 

Other Option:

 

4. AL (Amyloid Light chain): Is associated with primary amyloidosis, not secondary. Secondary amyloidosis is most often associated with AA (Amyloid A) protein, derived from the acute-phase reactant serum amyloid A.

 

Additional Information

 

A. Generalized/Systemic Amyloidosis

 

 

B. Localised Amyloidosis

 

 

C. Hereditary Amyloidosis

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain

questions.text: A young boy from high altitude came with fever and weakness and had the following reports Hemoglobin 17 gm%, TLC is 21,000 with neutrophils 25, lymphocytes 30, eosinophils 5, myelocytes and metamyelocytes 40 in peripheral smear. Next step in the investigation should be: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Erythropoietin levels

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia (Hb>16 g/dL). Erythropoietin levels should be determined to differentiate primary from secondary forms.

 

Polycythemia vera (PCV) is characterized by increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets (panmyelosis), but it is the increase in red cells (polycythemia), that is responsible for most of the clinical symptoms. PCV must be differentiated from relative polycythemia resulting from hemoconcentration and other causes of absolute polycythemia. PCV is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase JAK2.

 

In PCV the progenitor cells have markedly decreased requirements for erythropoietin and other hematopoietic growth factors due to constitutive JAK2 signaling. Accordingly, serum erythropoietin levels in PCV are very low, whereas secondary forms of absolute polycythemia have high erythropoietin levels.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Philadelphia chromosome: This test is relevant in diagnosing chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), not polycythemia. While the presence of immature myeloid cells (myelocytes and metamyelocytes) could suggest a myeloproliferative disorder, the patient's clinical presentation and high hemoglobin level are more consistent with polycythemia, making erythropoietin testing a more appropriate next step.

 

Option B. JAK mutation: Testing for the JAK2 mutation is crucial in confirming a diagnosis of PCV. However, before proceeding to this test, it is important to measure erythropoietin levels to differentiate between primary and secondary polycythemia. If erythropoietin levels are low, JAK2 mutation analysis would then be the next step.

 

Option D. Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain: This investigation is used to evaluate bone marrow fibrosis, which can occur in myeloproliferative disorders like PCV. However, it is not the first-line investigation in this scenario. The erythropoietin level is a less invasive test that provides critical information to guide further diagnostic steps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythropoietin levels should be measured to differentiate between primary and secondary polycythemia. In cases of polycythemia vera, erythropoietin levels are typically low due to constitutive JAK2 signaling, while secondary polycythemia is associated with high erythropoietin levels.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortans pathologic basis of disease, Pg 1161, 1242

choices.text: Chief cells
Stem cells
Parietal cells

questions.text: Cells lining the isthmus of the gastric pits? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stem cells  

 

The isthmus of the gastric pits, which is the region between the gastric pit and the gland, contains stem cells. These stem cells are crucial for the continuous regeneration of the epithelial lining of the stomach. They have the potential to differentiate into all the different types of cells found in the gastric glands, including surface mucous cells, mucous neck cells, parietal cells, chief cells, and enteroendocrine cells. The high turnover rate of gastric epithelium necessitates the presence of these stem cells in the isthmus to replace the cells lost due to the harsh acidic environment of the stomach.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chief cells: Chief cells are located in the base of the gastric glands and are responsible for secreting pepsinogen, which is the precursor to the digestive enzyme pepsin.

 

Option C. Parietal cells: Parietal cells are found in the neck and body of the gastric glands and are responsible for secreting hydrochloric acid (HCl) and intrinsic factor, which is crucial for vitamin B12 absorption.

 

Option D. Mucous cells: Mucous cells, specifically surface mucous cells, are found lining the gastric pits and are responsible for secreting mucus that protects the stomach lining from the acidic environment. Mucous neck cells are located in the neck of the gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The isthmus of the gastric pits is lined with stem cells, which are essential for the regeneration of the various cell types in the gastric glands, ensuring the maintenance of the gastric epithelium.

choices.text: Trinucleotide mutation in FMR-1 gene
Mental retardation
Large everted ears

questions.text: All of the following are features of fragile X syndrome except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Micro-orchidism

 

Macro-orchidism (large testicles) are seen in fragile X syndrome, not micro-orchidism.

 

Fragile X syndrome is caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome. This expansion leads to a deficiency in the FMRP protein, which is important for neural development and function. Males with fragile X syndrome often have macro-orchidism, which can be observed during childhood and becomes more apparent during puberty. Other physical features of fragile X syndrome may include a long and narrow face, prominent forehead and chin, and large ears that are often everted. Intellectual disability and behavioral problems are also common features of the syndrome.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding sirtuins? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Increases insulin sensitivity and thus glucose metabolism.
  2. Promotes genes that increase longevity.
  3. They are of 7 types.
  4. They are one of the types of histone deacetylases.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Sirtuins are a family of proteins that have been widely studied for their role in regulating various cellular processes, including aging, metabolism, and stress responses. Here's a detailed breakdown of each statement:

 

  1. Increases insulin sensitivity and thus glucose metabolism: Sirtuins, particularly SIRT1, have been shown to enhance insulin sensitivity and promote glucose metabolism, which is crucial for maintaining energy homeostasis.
  2. Promotes genes that increase longevity: Sirtuins are known to regulate gene expression in ways that promote longevity. They are involved in the deacetylation of proteins that contribute to cell survival, repair, and metabolism, which are associated with extended lifespan in various organisms.
  3. They are of 7 types: There are seven known sirtuins in humans, designated SIRT1 through SIRT7, each with specific functions in different cellular compartments.
  4. They are one of the types of histone deacetylases: Sirtuins function as NAD+-dependent deacetylases, a class of enzymes that remove acetyl groups from histone and non-histone proteins, influencing gene expression and protein activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sirtuins are a family of seven histone deacetylases involved in increasing insulin sensitivity, glucose metabolism, promoting genes associated with longevity, and playing a significant role in various cellular processes.

questions.text: Which of the following is useful for a patient having Haemophilia B?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fresh frozen plasma

 

Haemophilia B is characterized by a deficiency in factor IX. The treatment for haemophilia B focuses on supplementing the deficient factor IX. Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is an excellent source of factor IX and is therefore useful in treating haemophilia B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryoprecipitate: Incorrect. Cryoprecipitate is rich in factor VIII and is primarily used for treating haemophilia A, not haemophilia B.

 

Option C. Recombinant factor 8: Incorrect. Recombinant factor VIII is used to treat haemophilia A, which is a deficiency in factor VIII, not factor IX.

 

Option D. Cryo poor plasma: Incorrect. Although cryo poor plasma can still contain some factor IX, it is not the best choice compared to fresh frozen plasma. Cryo poor plasma is more commonly used for treating thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemophilia B is a genetic deficiency of Factor IX, also called Christmas disease.

 

It is an X-linked recessive bleeding disorder, causing:

 

  • Easy bruising
  • Hemarthroses
  • Prolonged bleeding after injury or surgery

 

For the treatment of haemophilia B, fresh frozen plasma is an effective source of factor IX. Recombinant factor IX would be the best treatment option if available.

questions.text: Apoptotic bodies comprise of: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytoplasm + nuclear fragment + organelle

 

Apoptotic bodies are formed during the process of apoptosis, or programmed cell death. Apoptosis involves the activation of caspase enzymes, endonucleases, and proteases, leading to the fragmentation of the dying cell. These cellular fragments, known as apoptotic bodies, contain components of the cell, including cytoplasm, nuclear fragments, and organelles. The presence of these components within the apoptotic bodies is a key characteristic of the apoptotic process.

 

 

 

 

TUNEL Staining (Mouse liver showing an apoptotic cell stained with TUNEL)

Apoptotic body is looks like a dense, eosinophilic structure,  the presence of a stepladder pattern on gel electrophoresis and TUNEL staining, which are both associated with the detection of apoptotic cells. These techniques help identify the fragmented DNA and cellular components present in apoptotic bodies.

 

 

Lane B – showing apoptosis as a stepladder pattern on gel electrophoresis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apoptotic bodies, formed during the process of apoptosis, comprise cytoplasm, nuclear fragments, and organelles of the dying cell.

questions.text: Which of the following bands will increase in serum electrophoresis in Nephrotic syndrome? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha 2 globulin

 

 

  • In Nephrotic syndrome, there is a marked increase in alpha 2 globulin levels on serum electrophoresis. This is due to the liver increasing production of some proteins as a compensatory response to heavy proteinuria, especially proteins like alpha 2 macroglobulin, which are too large to be lost through the glomerulus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gamma globulin: Typically decreased or normal in Nephrotic syndrome due to the loss of smaller immunoglobulins in the urine.

 

Option C. Beta globulin: Generally shows little change in Nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option D. Albumin: Markedly decreased in Nephrotic syndrome due to loss in the urine, which is a hallmark of the disease and responsible for the characteristic edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Nephrotic syndrome, Alpha 2 globulin increases on serum electrophoresis as a response to heavy proteinuria, while albumin significantly decreases leading to symptoms such as severe swelling and fluid accumulation in the body.

questions.text: A middle aged cement factory worker has developed mesothelioma. This is likely to be associated with: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asbestosis

 

Mesothelioma is a malignant tumor of the pleura (or less commonly, the peritoneum). The development of mesothelioma is closely linked with exposure to asbestos, which is commonly encountered in certain occupational settings, including cement factories.

 

Asbestosis:

 

  • Pathology: Asbestosis refers to chronic lung disease caused by inhaling asbestos fibers. The fibers can cause inflammation and scarring of lung tissue, leading to a restrictive lung disease.
  • Complications: Prolonged exposure to asbestos can lead to the development of mesothelioma, a malignant tumor of the pleura or peritoneum.
  • Occupational Exposure: Cement factory workers, construction workers, and shipbuilders are at higher risk of asbestos exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silicosis: Caused by inhalation of silica dust, leading to nodular pulmonary fibrosis. Not directly associated with mesothelioma.

 

Option C. Anthracosis: Associated with coal dust inhalation, leading to coal worker's pneumoconiosis, not mesothelioma.

 

Option D. Byssinosis: Associated with cotton dust inhalation, leading to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, not mesothelioma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mesothelioma is strongly associated with asbestos exposure, commonly found in occupations such as cement factory work, construction, and shipbuilding. Asbestosis can lead to significant complications, including mesothelioma.

 

Asbestos is a fibrous silicate mineral used in insulation, construction, and cement manufacturing.

 

  • Inhaled asbestos fibers lodge in the lungs and pleura, causing:
  • Interstitial fibrosis (asbestosis)
  • Pleural plaques
  • Mesothelioma
  • Increased risk of bronchogenic carcinoma
  • Even minimal exposure can be dangerous over time.

questions.text: The stain done on a section of liver shown below is: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sweet’s reticulin stain

 

Stain demonstrates reticular fibers of the liver and hence has to be reticulin stain.

 

On microscope - plump hepatocytes are surrounded by rims of atrophic hepatocytes. The variation in parenchymal architecture is not easily seen on an H&E stain, and reticulin staining is required to appreciate the changes in hepatocellular architecture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Warthin starry stain: This stain is typically used to identify organisms such as Helicobacter pylori or spirochetes and is not used for reticulin fibers.

 

Option B. Steiner silver stain: Steiner silver stain is used for the detection of certain microorganisms, like Legionella and Treponema, and is not related to reticulin fibers.

 

Option D. Grimelius silver stain: This stain is used for the detection of neuroendocrine cells by highlighting granules within these cells, and again, it is not related to the reticulin fibers of the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sweet’s reticulin stain is specifically used to demonstrate reticular fibers in the liver, allowing for the visualization of changes in hepatocellular architecture that are not apparent with H&E staining.

choices.text: It is mostly in children
It can be associated with MEN 2A

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement about a patient with a retroperitoneal mass, episodic hypertension, palpitations, and increased urinary VMA levels? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It can be associated with MEN 2A

 

The clinical scenario described is characteristic of pheochromocytoma, a catecholamine-secreting tumor that typically presents with episodic hypertension, palpitations, headaches, and elevated urinary vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) levels.

 

Pheochromocytomas are known to be associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN 2A), which involves mutations in the RET gene. Patients with MEN 2A often present with pheochromocytoma, medullary thyroid cancer, and parathyroid hyperplasia.

 

Remember – The genes associated with pheochromocytoma, includes the RET gene, P53 gene, VHL gene, and the succinate dehydrogenase B (SDHB) gene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is mostly in children: Pheochromocytomas are more common in adults, and only about 10% of cases occur in children. Therefore, this statement is incorrect as the majority of cases are found in adults.

 

Option B. It is usually malignant: Pheochromocytomas are benign in about 90% of cases. Malignancy is seen in only about 10% of cases, so this statement is incorrect.

 

Option C. It is mostly bilateral: Pheochromocytomas are predominantly unilateral. Bilateral tumors are seen in only 10% of cases, often in familial syndromes such as MEN 2A. Hence, this statement is not accurate for the majority of cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pheochromocytomas are catecholamine-secreting tumors associated with episodic hypertension and increased urinary VMA levels. They are commonly linked with MEN 2A syndrome, which involves RET gene mutations.

questions.text: Which stain is commonly used to differentiate the infarcted portion from the normal portion of the heart in a deceased patient who died due to myocardial infarction (MI)? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triphenyl Tetrazolium chloride

 

 

Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride stain used to differentiate the infarct portion to the normal portion of heart following image is showing triphenyl tetrazolium chloride stain where BRICK RED colour is showing normal tissue and PALE color is showing MI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methylene blue: This stain is commonly used for highlighting various cell structures but is not specific for differentiating infarcted myocardial tissue.

 

Option C. Congo red: This stain is used to identify amyloid deposits in tissues, not for myocardial infarction.

 

Option D. Oil red O: This is a fat-soluble dye used to stain lipids in tissues, not specific for myocardial infarction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride (TTC) stain is used to differentiate infarcted myocardial tissue from normal tissue, with normal tissue appearing brick red and infarcted tissue appearing pale.

questions.text: Reinke crystals are seen in which of the following gonadal tumours: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leydig cell tumor

 

  • Reinke crystals are a specific and distinguishing feature of Leydig cell tumors. These crystals are eosinophilic, rod-shaped, crystalline inclusions found in the cytoplasm of Leydig cells. Leydig cell tumors are non-germ cell, sex cord-stromal tumors of the testicles that are typically benign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seminoma: Does not feature Reinke crystals; characterized by uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei, often associated with lymphocytic infiltration.

 

Option B. Yolk sac Tumor: Lacks Reinke crystals; known for Schiller-Duval bodies and a pattern resembling endodermal sinus structures.

 

Option D. Sertoli cell Tumor: Also does not contain Reinke crystals; these tumors may show tubular or trabecular growth patterns and are often clinically silent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reinke crystals are pathognomonic of Leydig cell tumors of the testis and are useful in differentiating these from other testicular neoplasms.

questions.text: Which of the following proteins of human papilloma virus inactivates Rb gene? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) E7

 

Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is associated with several cancers, including cervical cancer. HPV has two key oncoproteins, E6 and E7, that play a crucial role in the pathogenesis of cancer by inactivating tumor suppressor proteins.

 

E7 protein binds to and inactivates the Rb (Retinoblastoma) gene, which is a crucial tumor suppressor that controls cell cycle progression. By inactivating Rb, E7 disrupts the regulation of the cell cycle, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation, a hallmark of cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E6: Targets and degrades p53 but does not inactivate Rb. E6 promotes the degradation of p53, leading to the loss of its tumor suppressor functions, such as apoptosis and DNA repair.

 

Option C. L1: L1 is a major capsid protein of HPV involved in the assembly of the viral particle but does not have a role in inactivating tumor suppressor genes.

 

Option D. L2: L2 is a minor capsid protein involved in viral genome packaging and entry into host cells but does not inactivate tumor suppressor genes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The E7 protein of Human Papillomavirus (HPV) inactivates the Rb gene, leading to disruption of the cell cycle and contributing to the development of cancer.

 

HPV Oncoproteins:

 

 

L1 protein is useful for making vaccine for HPV. (recent INICET ques)

choices.text: Owl’s Eye Appearance on Transverse Section

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Anitschkow cells is not true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Owl’s Eye Appearance on Transverse Section

 

Explanation: 

 

Anitschkow cells (also spelled Anitschkow) are a characteristic finding in rheumatic heart disease. These cells are activated macrophages (histiocytes) found in Aschoff bodies, which are pathognomonic for rheumatic fever. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon.
