This characteristic nuclear appearance gives them the name "caterpillar cells" due to their resemblance to a caterpillar on longitudinal section. The "owl's eye" appearance is not associated with Anitschkow cells but is typically seen in cytomegalovirus infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Modified Cardiac Histocytes - This is correct. Anitschkow cells are plump activated macrophages (histiocytes) that appear in the myocardium as part of the inflammatory response in rheumatic heart disease.

 

Option B. Caterpillar Appearance on Longitudinal Section - This is correct. The centrally condensed chromatin appears as a slender, wavy ribbon, giving Anitschkow cells their characteristic "caterpillar" appearance.

 

Option D. Pathognomonic of Rheumatic Heart Disease - This is correct. Anitschkow cells are found in Aschoff bodies, which are pathognomonic for rheumatic fever and rheumatic heart disease. These lesions represent a characteristic inflammatory response in the myocardium.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Anitschkow cells are distinctive activated macrophages with a "caterpillar" nuclear appearance (not "owl's eye") that are pathognomonic for rheumatic heart disease, typically found within Aschoff bodies in the myocardium.

questions.text: Which of the following causes vasodilation? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Histamine  

 

The most important mast cell–derived amine is histamine. Histamine causes intense smooth muscle contraction, increased vascular permeability, and increased mucus secretion by nasal, bronchial, and gastric glands.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thromboxane A2: Thromboxane A2 is an activator of platelet aggregation and vasoconstrictor.

 

Option C. Serotonin: Serotonin possesses both vasoconstrictor and vasodilator properties.

 

Option D. Leukotrienes C4: Leukotrienes C4 and D4 are the most potent vasoactive and spasmogenic agents known. On a molar basis, they are several thousand times more active than histamine in increasing vascular permeability and causing bronchial smooth muscle contraction. Leukotriene B4 is highly chemotactic for neutrophils, eosinophils, and monocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histamine is the primary mediator responsible for causing vasodilation, playing a critical role in the inflammatory response by increasing blood flow and vascular permeability.

questions.text: What does the following image show? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emperipolesis

 

The image shows the phenomenon of emperipolesis. Here, intact hematopoietic cells are seen within the cytoplasm of the host cell without any damage. In this case, a band neutrophil is seen inside a megakaryocyte.

 

A rare biological phenomenon called emperipolesis involves a cell penetrating another live cell. In emperipolesis, as opposed to phagocytosis, when the enveloped cell is destroyed by the macrophage's lysosomal enzymes, the cell can exit at any time without causing any structural or functional problems for either of them. This process can be either physiological or pathological. Histiocytes and Megakaryocytes generally participate in peripolesis. It is seen in Rosai-Dorfman disease and Hodgkin's disease are pathological circumstances when this process is observed.

 

NOTE:

 

Emperipolesis vs Entosis:

 

Emperipolesis is a cellular process in which one cell enters into another cell without being degraded or destroyed. This process occurs in various cell types, including immune cells and cancer cells, and is thought to play a role in cell-to-cell communication and immune surveillance. In emperipolesis, the engulfed cell remains intact and is usually released from the host cell after a certain period of time.

 

Entosis, on the other hand, is a cellular process in which one cell actively engulfs and digests another cell. This process occurs primarily in epithelial cells and is thought to play a role in tissue homeostasis and elimination of damaged or excess cells. In Entosis, the engulfed cell is degraded and digested by the host cell's lysosomes.

 

In summary, the main difference between emperipolesis and Entosis is that in emperipolesis, the engulfed cell remains intact and is usually released from the host cell, while in Entosis, the engulfed cell is degraded and digested by the host cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autophagy: This process involves the degradation of a cell's own components through the lysosomal machinery.

 

Option C. Phagocytosis: The process by which a cell engulfs and digests foreign particles or cells, typically leading to the degradation of the engulfed material.

 

Option D. Amoebic autophagy: Not a recognized term; may be confused with autophagy or phagocytosis processes seen in amoebas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emperipolesis is a unique process where one cell enters another without being destroyed, differentiating it from phagocytosis and entosis, with the host cell usually being a megakaryocyte or histiocyte.

questions.text: Given below is an electron microscopic image of the lung tissue. A patient infected with SARS-COV2 presents with ARDS. The infection would affect and expand which of the labelled layers? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A  

 

The image given in the question demonstrates the electron microscopic image of the blood-air barrier in the lungs. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) has been set in this patient with COVID-19. Damage to the endothelial (Labelled as A, with inflammation, is the key initiating event and the basis of lung damage. Neutrophils play a significant role in tissue injury in this condition.

 

 

 

The electron micrograph shows at high magnification three components of the air-blood barrier in the alveolar septum. Gaseous exchange occurs across, 1) the cytoplasm of a type I alveolar cell or pneumocyte, P1; 2) the fused basal laminas (basement membranes) of type I alveolar and endothelial cells, BM; and 3) the cytoplasm of an endothelial cell, E, enclosing a blood capillary. Note the erythrocyte, Er, present within the lumen of the blood capillary. A fourth component of the air-blood barrier, surfactant, is not preserved in routine histological sections.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basement Membrane: While the basement membrane is part of the blood-air barrier, it is not the primary site of injury in ARDS.

 

Option C. Type I Alveolar cell/Pneumocyte: Although these cells are affected in ARDS, the endothelial cells are typically the first to be damaged.

 

Option D. Erythrocyte: The erythrocyte is not structurally affected by ARDS but rather suffers the consequences of impaired gas exchange due to endothelial and alveolar damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ARDS, especially in cases associated with SARS-CoV-2 infection, the primary injury occurs in the endothelial cells of the blood-air barrier, leading to inflammation, increased permeability, and subsequent respiratory failure.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly involving the skin and respiratory tract. The patient's parents report that he has had multiple abscesses and lymphadenitis. Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test results show an abnormal pattern. What is the primary suspicion based on these findings? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic granulomatous disease

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly involving the skin and respiratory tract, along with a history of multiple abscesses and lymphadenitis in a young child, strongly suggests a primary immunodeficiency disorder. The abnormal dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test result further supports the diagnosis of chronic granulomatous disease (CGD).

 

CGD is a rare inherited disorder characterized by defective oxygen-dependent killing of microorganisms by phagocytic cells, such as neutrophils and macrophages. This defect is caused by mutations in the genes encoding components of the NADPH oxidase enzyme complex, which is responsible for generating reactive oxygen species (ROS) necessary for microbial killing. The inability to produce sufficient ROS leads to recurrent infections, especially with catalase-positive organisms.

 

The DHR test is a flow cytometry-based assay that measures the production of ROS by neutrophils after stimulation. An abnormal DHR test result, as seen in this patient, is consistent with the diagnosis of CGD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID) is a group of disorders characterized by defects in both cellular and humoral immunity.

 

X-linked SCID is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder characterized by chronic diarrhea, periodic respiratory infection, and acquired maternal T cell-mediated GVHD. Mutations in interleukin-2 receptor gamma (IL2RG) can result in X-SCID. While patients with SCID are also susceptible to recurrent infections, the presentation typically involves opportunistic infections and failure to thrive, which are not mentioned in this case.

 

Option C. Sialyl Lewis X defect, also known as leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 2 (LAD-2), is a rare disorder characterized by defective leukocyte rolling and adhesion due to a deficiency in the sialyl Lewis X ligand. While patients with LAD-2 may present with recurrent infections, the DHR test would not be abnormal in this condition.

 

Option D. Integrin defects, such as leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1 (LAD-1), are characterized by defective leukocyte adhesion and migration due to mutations in the genes encoding integrins. Although patients with LAD-1 may present with recurrent infections, the DHR test would not be abnormal in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic granulomatous disease should be suspected in a child presenting with recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly involving the skin and respiratory tract, along with a history of multiple abscesses and lymphadenitis, and an abnormal DHR test result.

choices.text: Most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries
Can be diagnosed with CECT
Improves with food rich in carbohydrates
Increased risk of GI lymphoma

questions.text: Which of the following is true about celiac disease? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased risk of GI lymphoma

 

Individuals with celiac disease have an increased risk of Gl lymphoma.

 

Celiac disease is also known as celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy. It is an immune mediated enteropathy triggered by the ingestion of gluten-containing cereals, such as barley, rye, oats & wheat (BROW) in genetically predisposed individuals. In countries where most people are Caucasians of European ancestry, celiac disease is a common disorder, with an estimated prevalence of 0.5% to 1%.

 

The histopathology is characterized by increased numbers of intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes (intraepithelial lymphocytosis), crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy. This loss of mucosal and brush-border surface area accounts for the malabsorption.

 

 

Noninvasive serologic tests are generally performed prior to biopsy. The most sensitive tests are the presence of IgA antibodies to tissue transglutaminase or IgA or IgG antibodies to deamidated gliadin. Anti-endomysial antibodies are highly specific but less sensitive than other antibodies.

 

Individuals with celiac disease have a higher-than-normal rate of malignancy. The most common celiac disease–associated cancer is enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma, an aggressive lymphoma of intraepithelial T lymphocytes. Small intestinal adenocarcinoma is also more frequent in individuals with celiac disease.

 

The treatment is lifelong gluten free diet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries: This is incorrect. While celiac disease can cause malnutrition due to malabsorption, it is not the most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries. Infectious diseases, poor diet, and other factors are more common causes.

 

Option B. Can be diagnosed with CECT: This is incorrect. Celiac disease is not typically diagnosed with contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT). The diagnosis is usually based on serologic tests for specific antibodies and confirmed by duodenal biopsy showing characteristic histopathological changes such as villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and intraepithelial lymphocytosis.

 

Option C. Improves with food rich in carbohydrates: This is incorrect. Celiac disease improves with a gluten-free diet, not with an increase in carbohydrates. The treatment requires strict lifelong avoidance of gluten.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease is associated with an increased risk of gastrointestinal lymphoma, specifically enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma, making it a critical long-term concern for individuals with this condition.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1518-1519

questions.text: What is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of myocarditis? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endo-myocardial biopsy

 

An endo-myocardial biopsy is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of myocarditis.

 

Active myocarditis is characterized by an interstitial inflammatory infiltrate associated with degenerating or apoptotic myocytes.

 

Etiological classification of myocarditis:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Magnetic Resonance Imaging: MRI can be used to detect myocardial inflammation and scarring, but it is not the gold standard. It is useful for non-invasive assessment but cannot definitively diagnose myocarditis without histological confirmation.

 

Option C. Brain Natriuretic Peptide (BNP): BNP is a biomarker used to assess heart failure but is not specific or sensitive for diagnosing myocarditis.

 

Option D. LDH1 to LDH2 ratio: This ratio is sometimes used in the context of myocardial infarction but does not have a role in diagnosing myocarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endo-myocardial biopsy remains the gold standard for diagnosing myocarditis, as it allows for direct histopathological examination of myocardial tissue.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1064

questions.text: Toluidine blue staining is used in the Identification of which of the following cells? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mast Cell

 

Toluidine blue is the special stain for mast cells.

 

Toluidine blue (also known as tolonium chloride) is an acidophilic metachromatic dye that selectively stains acidic tissue components (sulfates, carboxylates, and phosphate radicals). Toluidine blue (TB. has an affinity for nucleic acids, and therefore binds to nuclear material of tissues with a high DNA and RNA content.

 

It also intensely stains some substances leading to a change in color. This effect known as metachromasia.

 

  • Orthochromatic Staining - structures stained blue (Lymphocytes)
  • Metachromatic Staining - structures stained dark purple from polymeric aggregates formed when binding to high concentrations of polyanions (Mast cells)

 

Toluidine blue is often used to identify mast cells by virtue of heparin (which is very polyanionic. found in their secretion granules.

 

 

Application of Toluidine Blue

 

  1. Connective tissue mucins, especially acid mucins. The tissue stains purple to red, while the background is stained blue.
  2. Mast cell granules stain purple in color due to the presence of heparin and histamine.
  3. Amyloid stain blue but under polarized light they give a bright red birefringence.
  4. Endocrine cell granules are stained purple to red.
  5. Sulfatides stain red brown or yellow. Only lipids that are sufficiently acidic to induce a metachromatic shift are stained.
  6. Corynebacterium diphtheria contains granules with polymerized inorganic polyphosphate, which stains red violet color.
  7. Helicobacter stains dark blue against a variably blue background.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymphocyte: Lymphocytes can be stained with toluidine blue, but they show orthochromatic staining (blue), not the metachromasia that is characteristic of mast cells.

 

Option B. Fibroblast: Fibroblasts are not specifically identified by toluidine blue staining.

 

Option C. Macrophage: While macrophages can be stained with various dyes, they do not exhibit the metachromasia seen in mast cells with toluidine blue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Toluidine blue is primarily used to identify mast cells due to their characteristic metachromatic staining caused by the heparin in their granules.

questions.text: A child presents with curved lowered spine, shortened arms and legs, poor muscle tone and delayed milestones. His upper arms are affected more than the lower legs. Which of the following   is the inheritance of the disease? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AD

 

Achondroplasia is a genetic disorder that is characterized by dwarfism, with specific features including a curved lower spine (lordosis or kyphosis), shortened arms and legs (rhizomelic shortening), poor muscle tone, and delayed milestones. The upper arms (humerus) are more affected than the lower legs (femur). The condition is caused by mutations in the FGFR3 gene and follows an autosomal dominant (AD) inheritance pattern. This means only one copy of the mutated gene, inherited from one parent, is sufficient to cause the disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AR (Autosomal Recessive): This pattern requires both parents to pass on a copy of the mutated gene for the disorder to manifest. Achondroplasia does not follow this pattern.

 

Option B. XLD (X-linked Dominant): This inheritance pattern affects both males and females, but is not relevant to achondroplasia.

 

Option C. XLR (X-linked Recessive): This pattern primarily affects males and requires the mother to be a carrier. Achondroplasia does not follow this pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achondroplasia has autosomal dominant inheritance, requiring only one copy of the mutated FGFR3 gene to cause the disorder.

choices.text: Prostate carcinoma
Breast carcinoma
Stomach carcinoma

questions.text: Predominantly osteoblastic secondaries are seen in: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prostate carcinoma

 

Predominantly osteoblastic secondaries are seen in prostate carcinoma.

 

Metastatic bone tumors: Metastatic bone tumors outnumber primary bone cancers as the most common type of skeletal malignancy.

 

Osteoblastic (or sclerotic) bone deposition is seen in prostate cancer, carcinoid, small cell lung cancer, Hodgkin lymphoma, and medulloblastoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breast carcinoma: While breast cancer can metastasize to bone, it typically results in osteolytic (bone-destroying) rather than osteoblastic lesions.

 

Option C. Stomach carcinoma: Metastases from stomach cancer to bone are relatively rare and typically do not exhibit osteoblastic activity.

 

Option D. Bone carcinoma: This option is less specific and generally refers to primary bone cancers, which are different from the metastatic osteoblastic lesions seen in prostate cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Osteoblastic metastases are a hallmark of prostate carcinoma, unlike breast and stomach carcinomas which are more likely to cause osteolytic or no bone lesions respectively.

questions.text: Secondary amyloidosis is a complication of: (NEET 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)

 

Explanation:

 

Secondary amyloidosis, also known as AA amyloidosis, commonly arises as a complication of chronic inflammatory conditions such as Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA). In RA, prolonged inflammation stimulates increased production of serum amyloid A (SAA), a precursor protein synthesized in the liver. Over time, this leads to the deposition of AA amyloid in various organs, contributing to additional organ dysfunction and complications in RA patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plasmacytosis and C. Multiple myeloma: These conditions are typically associated with AL amyloidosis, which involves the deposition of amyloid derived from immunoglobulin light chains, not AA amyloid associated with inflammatory conditions.

 

Option D. None: Incorrect, as RA is a well-known cause of secondary amyloidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary amyloidosis (AA amyloidosis) is often a complication of chronic inflammatory diseases such as Rheumatoid Arthritis, where sustained inflammation leads to the production and deposition of AA protein.

questions.text: Which of the following is the color of vacutainer containing sodium fluoride as a content? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Grey

 

The grey-colored vacutainer contains sodium fluoride as an anticoagulant. Sodium fluoride acts by inhibiting glycolysis, which is the breakdown of glucose by enzymes, releasing energy and pyruvic acid. By inhibiting this process, sodium fluoride preserves the glucose levels in the blood sample, making it ideal for the estimation of blood glucose and alcohol levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Red: Red tubes typically do not contain an anticoagulant and are used for serum tests where the blood is allowed to clot before centrifugation.

 

Option C. Blue: Blue tubes usually contain sodium citrate as an anticoagulant, used primarily for coagulation studies such as PT and PTT.

 

Option D. Yellow: Yellow tubes may contain ACD (acid-citrate-dextrose) or SPS (sodium polyanethol sulfonate), used for blood cultures or blood bank studies.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: All of the following conditions are associated with Neurosecretory bodies except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adrenal cortical tumor

 

Neurosecretory bodies are not seen in adrenal cortical tumors.

 

Adrenocortical neoplasms produce aldosterone. Primary hyperaldosteronism due to a solitary aldosterone-secreting adenoma is Conn syndrome.

 

Microscopically, aldosterone-producing adenomas show spironolactone bodies which are eosinophilic, laminated cytoplasmic inclusions found after treatment with spironolactone.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medullary thyroid carcinoma: Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a type of thyroid cancer that originates from parafollicular C-cells, which are neuroendocrine cells. These cells secrete calcitonin and often contain neurosecretory granules.

 

Option B. Pituitary adenoma: Pituitary adenomas are tumors of the pituitary gland, many of which are neuroendocrine in nature. They can produce hormones such as prolactin, growth hormone, or ACTH, and neurosecretory granules can be found in these tumors.

 

Option C. Paraganglioma: Paragangliomas are tumors that arise from paraganglia, which are collections of neuroendocrine cells. These cells are closely related to the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems and often contain neurosecretory granules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurosecretory bodies are associated with neuroendocrine tumors, but not with adrenal cortical tumors, which originate from the adrenal cortex and are involved in steroid hormone production.

 

Tumors associated with neurosecretory granules

choices.text: B cells, dendritic cells, mononuclear phagocytes

questions.text: Among the following, which cells have MHC class II? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) B cells, dendritic cells, mononuclear phagocytes

 

Class II major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules are mainly expressed on macrophages, B lymphocytes, and dendritic cells. These cells present ingested antigens to T-cells.

 

Class I major histocompatibility complex are expressed on all nucleated cells

 

Class III major histocompatibility complex are some components of the complement system (C2 and C4) coded on HLA complex but are not associated with HLA expression and are not used in antigen identification.

 

 

MHC antigens present on the cell surface help the macrophage in its function of bacterial antigen recognition i.e., they help to identify self from foreign, and accordingly present the foreign antigen to T cells (CD4+ or CD8+) or to B cells.

 

MHC I are located on a portion of chromosome 6p of all nucleated cells of the body and platelets. These genes occupy four regions or loci—A, B, C and D, on the short (p) arm of chromosome 6 and exhibit marked variation in allelic genes at each locus. Therefore, the product of HLA antigens is highly polymorphic.

 

The genes encoding HLA molecules are clustered on the short arm of chromosome 6.

 

Role of MHC/ HLA typing include:

 

  1. Organ Transplantation
  2. Regulation of immune system
  3. Association of diseases with HLA. An increasing number of diseases have been found to have association with some specific histocompatibility antigens. Ex:
  4. Inflammatory disorders e.g., ankylosing spondylitis
  5. Autoimmune disorders e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, insulin dependent diabetes mellitus.
  6. Inherited disorders of metabolism e.g., idiopathic haemochromatosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. NK cells: While natural killer (NK) cells play a role in immune responses, they do not express MHC class II molecules.

 

Option B. All nucleated cells: This describes MHC Class I expression, not MHC Class II.

 

Option D. Platelets: Although platelets are derived from nucleated cells, they do not express MHC Class II molecules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MHC Class II molecules are primarily expressed on antigen presenting cells (B cells, dendritic cells, and mononuclear phagocytes), which are essential for antigen presentation to T-helper cells.
